abstracts.cdata!:
The project has been rated as
            unsatisfactory, with unlikely sustainability, although
            institutional development impacts are modest, and, while the
            Bank performance was satisfactory, the performance of the
            Borrower is rated unsatisfactory. Lessons specific to this
            operation suggest the project would have been better planned
            as a standard investment loan, particularly since there was
            no emergency at the time in Dominica, for it would have
            enabled better preparation of procurement, and institutional
            arrangements before appraisal.  Nonetheless, the
            Vulnerability Reduction Fund (VRF) employing local
            population in small-scale prevention works was successful in
            Dominica, employing local populations, being a cost
            effective way to reduce risks and raise community awareness.
            However, the cost of works designed for Dominica was far out
            of line with neighboring countries, which was the main
            reason they could not be implemented under the project.
            Lessons relevant to emergency operations suggest it would
            have been preferable to process the various loans/credits
            for OECS countries, as separate projects, part of a broader
            program, but not integrated into one horizontal APL;
            priority in this type of projects should be given to
            prevention, immediate measures to reactivate economic
            activity, and careful assessment of longer-term
            reconstruction priorities and designs; and, careful
            attention should be given to the project unit manpower,
            particularly in the absence of local capacity.
